choices.text: Prevents alveoli collapse and atelectasis of lung
Increases venous return and maintains cardiac output

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery in the prone position is maintained on mechanical ventilation with PEEP. What is the significance of using PEEP in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Prevents alveoli collapse and atelectasis of lung

The significance of using positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in the given clinical scenario is to help keep the alveoli open, preventing collapse (atelectasis), which is especially important in the prone position where certain lung regions might be more susceptible to collapse.
This is crucial in conditions where the lungs are prone to collapse, such as Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) or when the patient is in a prone position during surgery. By maintaining open alveoli, PEEP improves gas exchange, which increases oxygen levels in the blood.

choices.text: It is made of Lignocaine and ropivacaine

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about eutectic mixture of local anesthetic (EMLA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Methohemoglobinemia is a side effect

Methemoglobinemia can develop when high doses of prilocaine are administered, typically over 600 mg.

EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetic) is a topical mixture containing prilocaine. The risk of methemoglobinemia is increased in neonates with metabolic disorders or in those receiving drugs that can impair the reduction of methemoglobin.

choices.text: It can cause damage to the teeth
It can be used in conscious patients
It can be safely used in facial trauma cases

questions.text: An anesthetist used the airway device shown in the image given below on a patient. Which among the following statements is true regarding the adjunct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It can be used in conscious patients

The image shows a nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it can be used in conscious patients.

questions.text: In the following condition as shown in the radiograph, which of the following procedures would be difficult to perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tracheostomy

Tracheostomy would be difficult to perform in this case of pneumothorax with tracheal deviation.

The trachea is displaced from its usual midline position, making it challenging to accurately locate and access the trachea for the incision. The tracheostomy procedure requires precise placement to ensure proper airway management and avoid complications.

questions.text: A COVID-19 patient admitted to the ICU on mechanical ventilation suddenly develops hypoxia. The patient has decreased breath sounds on the left side and increased intrathoracic pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Pneumothorax

This patient in the above clinical scenario has developed a sudden onset of hypoxia, decreased breath sounds on one side, and increased intrathoracic pressure, along with an X- ray showing hyper lucency in the left side with tracheal and mediastinal shift to the right side is suggestive of a diagnosis of Pneumothorax.

choices.text: Defibrillate, check rhythm and then start CPR
Defibrillate followed by CPR for 2min, and check rhythm
Stop CPR and do cardioversion at 2 joules/kg

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with drowsiness and refusal to feed. On examination, the child is in a stuporous state. The ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Defibrillate followed by CPR for 2min, and check rhythm

The given ECG showing polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, which is a shockable rhythm, in a stuporous paediatric patient warrants immediate defibrillation followed by CPR for 2 minutes.

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, especially in a paediatric patient, is often associated with severe underlying conditions and is a life-
threatening rhythm disturbance. Immediate defibrillation is critical for restoring a normal rhythm.

questions.text: A patient underwent gastrectomy for gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following vitamins needs to be supplemented in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Vitamin B12

A patient who has undergone gastrectomy for gastric adenocarcinoma requires vitamin B12 supplementation due to impaired absorption. Vitamin B12 absorption depends on intrinsic factor, secreted by gastric parietal cells, and involves its release from dietary proteins by gastric acid and pepsin. After binding with cobalophilin in saliva, it is freed in the jejunum to bind with intrinsic factor, allowing absorption in the distal ileum. Gastrectomy reduces intrinsic factor production, making supplementation necessary to prevent deficiency.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child from a southern Indian state, hailing from a poor family, presents with rough and scaly skin. The child’s diet lacks vegetables and fruits. After treatment with linseed oil, Vitamin A, and Vitamin B, the symptoms subsided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phrynoderma

The presence of rough, scaly cutaneous lesions, combined with a dietary history lacking fruits and vegetables, is indicative of phrynoderma. Phrynoderma consists of keratotic follicular papules typically found on the elbows and knees, but they can also appear on the shoulders, neck, back, thighs, buttocks, and abdomen. Often referred to as "toad skin" due to their rough, cone-shaped appearance, these lesions can result from deficiencies in vitamins A, B complex, C, and E, as well as essential fatty acids.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department with intense abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Laboratory tests reveal serum triglyceride levels exceeding 2000 mg/dl. What deficiency might be contributing to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Apolipoprotein C II

Elevated triglyceride levels and symptoms of acute pancreatitis are likely due to a deficiency in apolipoprotein C II. This lipoprotein serves as a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase, which cleaves chylomicrons. A defect in apo C II leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency), resulting in inactive lipoprotein lipase, slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, and low LDL and HDL levels. Patients typically present with eruptive xanthomas and acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: After the age of 12, the boy had an intellectual disability. On examination, fingernail abrasions, excessive biting of lips, and increased levels of serum uric acid were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lesch-Nyhan disease

The clinical scenario of self-mutilation and hyperuricemia is most indicative of Lesch-Nyhan disease. This X-linked recessive disorder results from a complete deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), impairing the salvage of hypoxanthine and guanine. This leads to elevated levels of phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and increased purine synthesis, which ultimately results in higher uric acid levels.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with features of lethargy, and poor oral intake. On examination, a cataract was seen. Urine Benedict’s test was positive but negative for Glucose. What will be the enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

The given clinical scenario of a neonate presenting with lethargy, and poor oral intake, with examination revealing a cataract and urine benedict’s test was positive but negative for glucose, is suggestive of classical galactosemia and enzyme deficient is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a rare homozygous recessive condition presented with ectopia lentis. In the peripheral smear, there was no megaloblastic anemia. Later, he was found to have elevated homocysteine levels in the blood. Which of the following supplementations will help the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pyridoxine

In a patient with homocystinuria, pyridoxine (vitamin B6) can be used as supplementation. Classical homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder primarily caused by cystathionine β-synthase deficiency, leading to elevated homocysteine levels. Symptoms include intellectual disability, subluxated lenses, long slender limbs, arachnodactyly, and thrombi. Its skeletal features often resemble those of Marfan syndrome. Additionally, folic acid and vitamin B12 deficiencies can also cause homocystinuria with megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: You received a message from your friend, a person who recently visited his doctor due to concerns about potential exposure to hazardous materials. He is worried about respiratory issues and other health effects. Serum porphobilinogen levels are decreased. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lead poisoning The test for coproporphyrinogen levels is used as a screening test to diagnose lead poisoning. Lead inhibits the enzymes delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase and ferrochelatase, which are involved in heme synthesis. ALA is converted to porphobilinogen by ALA dehydratase, inhibited by lead. So, serum porphobilinogen levels are decreased in lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of persistent delayed developmental milestones, and hyperpigmented macular lesions on the body which are more pronounced on exposure to sunlight. What is the error in DNA multiplication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nucleotide excision repair

The history suggests xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair. This autosomal recessive disorder results in an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV radiation, leading to hypersensitivity to UV exposure and subsequent clinical effects.

questions.text: A patient with a family history of coronary heart disease presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum LDL to be 280 mg/dL and triglyceride levels was 398 mg/dl. What is the likely defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

LDL receptor defect

The clinical features of tendon xanthomas, along with elevated serum LDL and triglyceride levels, suggest familial hypercholesterolemia, which results from a defect in LDL receptors. This inherited condition, also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia, leads to reduced uptake of LDL and cholesterol, resulting in increased blood levels of both. Patients with this disorder face a higher risk of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

questions.text: Which food item among these is the primary source of thiamine in Indians?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

In the Indian diet, chapati and rice serve as the primary sources of thiamine (vitamin B1). The thiamine content in various foods, listed in decreasing order, is as follows: gingelly seeds, groundnut, Bengal gram, whole wheat, and rice. Notably, gingelly (sesame) seeds contain the highest levels of thiamine among these foods.

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after ingesting 10 tablets of Phenobarbital. Which of the following components of the ETC is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Complex I to Q

Phenobarbital is a barbiturate that inhibits the transfer of electrons from complex I (NADH-Q oxidoreductase) to coenzyme Q in the electron transport chain. By blocking this step, it prevents NADH from being oxidized and reduces the flow of electrons, leading to a decrease in oxygen consumption.

questions.text: A child presents to you with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A trephine biopsy aspirate shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glucocerebrosidase

The given clinical scenario of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing Gaucher’s cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. The deficient enzyme is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

questions.text: Identify the image shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chocolate cyst of ovary The given image shows a chocolate cyst of the ovary. Chocolate cysts of the ovaries represent the most important manifestation of endometriosis. Ovaries are frequently Involved bilaterally. It is lined by columnar epithelium.

choices.text: Opinion of 1 doctor is enough upto 24 weeks
Termination allowed between 20-24 weeks only if detrimental to mother’s life
Can terminate pregnancy upto 24 weeks for sexual assault

questions.text: A 14-year-old rape victim is 22 weeks pregnant and she would like to terminate her pregnancy. Which of the following is done under the MTP Act?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Can terminate pregnancy upto 24 weeks for sexual assault According to the MTP Act with 2021 amendments, pregnancy can be terminated upto 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations.

choices.text: Midpoint of anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: A ventouse vacuum was placed at the flexion point. What is the correct statement regarding flexion point?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 3 cm from posterior fontanelle An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point which is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.

questions.text: A primigravida who is a known case of bronchial asthma develops PPH. Which of the following needs to be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Carboprost The drug carboprost is contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma. Carboprost is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPH that is unresponsive to oxytocin. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum dose is 2mg.

questions.text: A patient with a carcinoma cervix lesion showing cervical growth extending to the pelvic side wall along with the presence of hydronephrosis. What is the stage of the tumour?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) III B Cervical cancer with hydronephrosis is classified as Stage III B according to FIGO staging. Cervical cancer is the second most common gynaecological cancer. The FIGO staging uses clinical, radiological, or pathological findings to stage cervical cancer from Stage I to IV Stage III cervical carcinoma involves the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, hydronephrosis, and lymph node involvement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with a mass per vagina, as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Uterovaginal prolapse grade 4 In the given image, the cervix has descended outside the vaginal orifice suggesting the diagnosis of grade IV utero- vaginal prolapse. The descent of one or more genital organs below their normal anatomical position is called pelvic organ prolapse (POP). It occurs when the muscles and tissues that support the pelvic organs become weakened or damaged, leading to one or more organs bulging into the vaginal canal.

questions.text:
A woman at 37 weeks of gestation comes to the OPD for an antenatal checkup. She is on warfarin for prosthetic valves. What would be the management of this patient?

LMWH-Low molecular weight heparin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Change to LMWH The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 37 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in the mother during the 2nd trimester. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, fetal anticoagulation, and fetal embryopathy if used in the 1st trimester.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with short stature has primary amenorrhea and has not attained puberty yet. Identify the chromosomal defect as shown in the image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Turner’s syndrome The given karyotyping image shows a “45 XO” abnormality, which is seen in Turner’s syndrome. Clinical features of Turner’s syndrome include short stature, low posterior hairline, broad chest, widely spaced nipples, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, cubitus valgus, and pigmented nevi.

questions.text: The illustration given below is used for which female genital pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Prolapse The given image shows POP-Q (pelvic organ prolapse quantification) system which was described by the Interrnational Continence Society for the prolapse of pelvic organs

questions.text: A teenage girl presents with primary amenorrhea, normal breast and pubic hair development with normal uterus & ovaries. What is the karyotype?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 46 XX The given clinical scenario is that of a female with primary amenorrhea, preservation of secondary characteristics with normal uterus & ovaries and an image showing imperforate hymen. The karyotype is normal, i.e, 46 XX karyotype.

questions.text: A female complaints of dysuria since 4 days associated with pelvic pain and abnormal vaginal discharge. Pap smear image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Human papilloma virus This patient with symptoms of dysuria, pelvic pain, and abnormal vaginal discharge and the above pap smear shows large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo which is suggestive of koilocytes, which is a characteristic feature of Infection caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady with 27 weeks of gestation has multiple congenital malformations in the fetus on radiological investigations. The parents want to terminate the pregnancy for which they went to the MTP board. Who is not a part of the MTP board?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lawyer A lawyer is not a part of the medical board. According to the MTP Act with 2021 amendments, a medical board consisting of an obstetrician, a paediatrician, a radiologist and a person appointed by the state.

questions.text: A woman at 30 weeks of gestation presents with pain and redness in the calf region. A diagnosis of DVT is made. Which of the following would you use in the management of the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) LMWH The pregnant woman with DVT at 30 weeks of gestation will be managed by low molecular weight heparin. LMWH is the drug of choice in the management of DVT in any trimester of pregnancy, as it does not cross the placenta to cause fetal malformations. It has better bioavailability. Longer half-life, predictable dose response and reduced adverse effects like osteoporosis and thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a prior breech delivery had an uneventful LSCS. She was later admitted to the ER due to antepartum hemorrhage and underwent another LSCS, during which she experienced significant blood loss, leading to the need for an obstetric hysterectomy. Based on this information, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Placenta accreta syndrome The given clinical scenario of this woman with previous LSCS, bleeding per vaginum during pregnancy with hysterectomy image showing placenta adherent to the uterine wall suggests that it is a case of placenta accreta syndrome. Placenta accreta is described as an abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. It is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.

choices.text: Urine output is 60 ml in 4 hours

questions.text: A patient with 32 weeks of gestation had tachycardia and a blood pressure of 160/110 mm of Hg. On examination, she had pedal edema and lab investigations showed proteinuria. Pritchard regimen with magnesium sulphate was started. What is the indication to stop MgSO4?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Urine output is 60 ml in 4 hours A urine output of 60 ml in 4 hours (<30ml/hr) is an indication to stop MgSO4 to prevent magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labour. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L

choices.text: Check for congenital anomalies of the fetus but not look for the sex
Check for congenital anomalies, the sex of the child and tell her if it is a female child
Check for congenital anomalies, the sex of the child and do not tell her
Only check routine ANC and do not do USG

questions.text: A G5P4 female comes for her routine scan. She is already a mother of 4 girl children and wants a boy this time. She is now interested to know the sex of the current child. According to PCPNDT act, what should you do as a radiologist?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Check for congenital anomalies of the fetus but not look for the sex According to PCPNDT act, the radiologist should check for congenital anomalies of the fetus but not look for the sex. Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques Act, 1994 is an act of the Parliament of India enacted to stop female foeticides and arrest the declining sex ratio in India.

questions.text: A P1L1 woman, with a history of uneventful previous delivery, presents with secondary infertility and amenorrhea for 2 years. The laparoscopy performed is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tuberculosis The clinical scenario of secondary infertility following a previous uncomplicated delivery, along with laparoscopy images showing multiple granulomatous foci, suggests genital tuberculosis. This condition is typically secondary to a primary infection, most commonly in the lungs (50%), but can also originate from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, or the gastrointestinal tract. It usually spreads through the bloodstream or lymphatic system.

choices.text: Liquid based cytology, Cervical biospy, HPV antigen testing
Pap smear, Cervical biopsy, HCV testing
Pap smear, Cervical biopsy, HBV DNA

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came with complaints of spotting and foul-smelling discharge. On per speculum examination, cervical erosions were present. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation required?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Liquid based cytology, Cervical biospy, HPV antigen testing For a patient presenting with spotting, foul discharge, and cervical erosion—indicative of cervical cancer—the most appropriate investigations include liquid-based cytology, cervical biopsy, and HPV antigen testing (Option A). In liquid-based cytology, a plastic spatula is used to collect samples, which are then placed in a liquid fixative (methanol). This process helps eliminate blood, mucus, and inflammatory cells, allowing for clearer examination of the epithelial cells. The cells are then filtered and transferred onto a glass slide to create a monolayer, facilitating effective cervical cancer screening.

questions.text:
A P1L1 woman had delivered a baby 8 hrs before by vaginal delivery. What is the earliest time to insert an IUCD?
IUCD-Intra uterine contraceptive device
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Within 48 hours The earliest opportunity to insert an IUCD is within 48 hours. A postpartum IUCD (PPIUCD) can be placed in the following scenarios: (a) post-placental, within 10 minutes after the placenta is delivered (b) within 48 hours after delivery (c) during a cesarean section (d) 4-6 weeks postpartum. Inserting a PPIUCD generally has a lower risk of perforation, although the expulsion rate may be slightly higher.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a history suggestive of hyperthyroidism at 8 weeks of POG. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Propylthiouracil The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU). It is because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole or methimazole.

questions.text:
In the absence of other obstetric complications in twin pregnancies A and B. What is the preferred mode of delivery for A and B respectively?

Image A: 1st twin in breech and 2nd twin in transverse

Image B: Both twins in cephalic
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. LSCS B. Vaginal delivery Image A shows 1st twin in the breech presentation and Image B shows 1st twin in the vertex presentation, Therefore the mode of delivery for images A and B would be LSCS and Vaginal delivery respectively. (Option B)

questions.text: A G3P2 patient with preeclampsia develops seizures and is started on the Pritchard regimen. What level of serum magnesium should be maintained in this patient in order to prevent seizures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 4-7 meq/L The clinical picture is suggestive of eclampsia and to control fits, optimum serum magnesium levels of 4-7 mEq/L have to be maintained.

questions.text: A neonate has bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications. She also has hydrocephalus. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Toxoplasma gondi The presence of bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications and hydrocephalus in a neonate is suggestive of congenital toxoplasmosis. The characteristic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Clinical manifestations apart from the triad include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia.

choices.text: 1- Brain, 2- Waldeyer’s ring, 3- somatic growth, 4- Testicular growth

questions.text: What is represented by each of the following growth curves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1- Brain, 2- Waldeyer’s ring, 3- somatic growth, 4- Testicular growth

The correct answer is 1- Brain, 2- Waldeyer’s ring, 3- somatic growth, 4- Testicular growth.

Curve 1: The neural growth(brain) attains 90% of the growth by the age of 2 years.

Curve 2: The tonsils are collections of lymphatic tissue located within the pharynx. They collectively form a ringed arrangement, known as 

Waldeyer’s ring. Tonsils/lymphatic growth in children occur between 4-8 years of age and then shrink down in adult age.

Curve 3: Somatic growth shows a sigmoid curve, rapid growth in the initial years, and then during puberty.

Curve 4: Testicular growth/Gonadal growth starts during puberty, before that the curve is flat.

questions.text: A mother brought her 2-year-old child to the OPD with complaints of lack of weight gain, abdominal pain on eating, and poor eating habits. The child was advised gluten-free diet after which there was improvement in the general condition and weight gain. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Celiac disease

The clinical presentation and the histopathological findings are suggestive of celiac disease.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where HLA DQ2 and DQ8 are expressed. In the small intestine, peptides of gluten are presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation. Antiendomysial and anti-tTG antibodies are found in serological studies.

choices.text: 4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 2.5mg
4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 7.5mg
4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + Sulphadoxine 1500mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 2.5mg
4 tablets of Artesunate 45mg + Sulphadoxine 1500mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 7.5mg

questions.text: A man presents with mixed infection of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum in a health centre in Rajasthan. What is the dosage of the treatment given on the second day?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 4 tablets of Artesunate 50mg + 6 tablets of Primaquine 2.5mg On the second day of treatment for a mixed infection with Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum, the prescribed dosage is 4 tablets of Artesunate (50 mg each) and 6 tablets of Primaquine (2.5 mg each). This treatment regimen is designed to effectively target both the blood stages of Plasmodium falciparum using an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) and the liver stages of Plasmodium vivax with Primaquine, ensuring thorough management of the infection.

questions.text: Which drug is used to treat multiple myeloma that is known to cause reactivation of Herpes Zoster?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bortezomib Bortezomib is the drug used to treat multiple myeloma and may lead to the reactivation of Herpes Zoster. As a proteasome inhibitor, bortezomib plays a key role in managing both newly diagnosed and relapsed multiple myeloma. It can be administered either intravenously or subcutaneously, with the dosage varying based on the disease stage, administration route, and the patient's medical history. This medication is associated with an increased risk of reactivating herpesviruses, including Herpes Zoster

choices.text: There is no allergic sensitization to aspirin and its metabolites
Occur on exposure to only aspirin
Occurs with exposure to other NSAIDs too that block COX 1

questions.text: A patient presented with breathing”difficulty and nasal polyposis when he took aspirin for fever. He faced this issue previously too when he took aspirin. Which among the following is not true about this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Occur on exposure to only aspirin The diagnosis for this patient with breathing difficulty and nasal polyposis, triggered by aspirin, a COX-1 inhibitor is aspirin-induced asthma, also known as Samter’s triad. The staternent that is not true is that “it occurs on exposure to only aspirin”, as this condition can also be triggered by other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, and is not restricted to just aspirin alone.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presented with urinary incontinence. She also has cognition decline and dementia. Which of the following drugs is useful for treating urinary incontinence?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tolterodine Tolterodine is effective for managing urinary incontinence in a 75-year-old female with cognitive decline and dementia. As a muscarinic receptor antagonist, it specifically targets the urinary bladder, helping to reduce side effects compared to other antimuscarinic medications. This selectivity is particularly beneficial for patients with cognitive issues. Since tolterodine is metabolized by CYP2D6, its dosage may need adjustment based on individual CYP2D6 activity, making it a suitable choice for minimizing adverse effects while addressing urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a two-week history of persistent fever, fatigue, and pallor, along with easy bruising and gum bleeding. Examination reveals pallor, petechiae on his legs, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy. Blood tests indicate severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and an elevated white blood cell count with blast cells. What is the best initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prednisolone + vincristine The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), and standard initial treatment in children includes a chemotherapy regimen with drugs like prednisolone and vincristine during the induction phase.

questions.text: Lignocaine is used in a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose of this drug depends upon which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Volume of distribution

The volume of distribution of the drug determines the loading dose of the drug.

Loading Dose =  Volume of distribution x Desired steady- state plasma concentration.

When the time to reach a steady-state is long, as it is for drugs with long half-lives, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of the drug in plasma to the target concentration.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease was having frequent attacks of renal colic. Which of the following diuretics is used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hydrochlorothiazide In a hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease who frequently experiences renal colic, hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is commonly prescribed. Thiazide diuretics are especially effective for calcium oxalate kidney stones as they lower urinary calcium excretion. They function by targeting the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron, inhibiting the Na+Cl- co-transporter. This inhibition reduces intracellular sodium levels, prompting compensatory mechanisms that enhance calcium reabsorption into the bloodstream.

questions.text: Identify the drug marked as ‘X’ in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amino caproic acid

The drug marked as ‘X’ in the image is aminocaproic acid.

Ε-Aminocaproic acid, a lysine analogue that competes with plasminogen for binding sites on fibrin. By blocking this interaction, ε-Aminocaproic acid prevents the conversion of plasminogen into plasmin, thereby inhibiting fibrinolysis. This action makes it a useful agent for reversing the effects of fibrinolytic therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-adrenergic blockers are beneficial for patients with reduced ejection fraction and can reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing exacerbations over a few years?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bisoprolol

The beta-adrenergic blocker that is useful in patients with reduced ejection fraction and can reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing exacerbations over a few years is bisoprolol.

Bisoprolol is preferred for use in patients having heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

questions.text: Which drug is used for maintenance therapy in opium addiction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Buprenorphine The drug used among the following options for maintenance therapy in opium addiction is buprenorphine. Buprenorphine is a partial Mu-opioid agonist and an antagonist at delta and kappa receptors. It is widely used both as an analgesic for chronic pain conditions, such as cancer pain, and as a treatment for opioid dependence, serving as an alternative to methadone.

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent surgery has complaints of nausea and vomiting. He was prescribed a drug called aprepitant. What is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NK-1 antagonist The class of drugs most preferred in patients suffering from postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), following surgery are the NK1 antagonists like aprepitant. Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin- 1 (NK-1) receptors. NK1 antagonists inhibit substance "P at" central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, fosaprepitant are examples of NK1 antagonists. It also acts on the chemotrigger zone whose location is shown below.

questions.text: What are the effects of posterior lesions in a Brodmann’s area 22 in a stroke patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Receptive Speech Function

A posterior lesion in Brodmann’s area 22, which is located in the superior temporal gyrus, typically affects receptive speech function. It is the sensory speech area.

The patient will most likely have Wernicke’s aphasia due to the damage to Wernicke’s area – area 22.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female went on vacation and fell asleep while sitting on a beach. After some time she woke with sunburn. Later when she went back home, she experienced pain while taking a warm bath (40°C). Which of the following receptors is responsible for the pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Innocuos thermal receptor – allodynia

The receptors responsible for this are innocuous thermal receptors which have perceived ordinarily non-noxious stimulus (i.e., warm bath) as severe pain also known as allodynia.

In this case, the warm bath at 40°C (typically not painful) causes pain due to sunburn, which sensitizes the skin. After sunburn, the skin becomes more sensitive, and thermal receptors that usually detect warmth now trigger pain signals in response to non-painful thermal stimuli, leading to allodynia.

choices.text: Increased membrane potential of the oocyte
Decreased membrane potential of the oocyte

questions.text: To prevent polyspermy, which reaction occurs in the zona pellucida of the oocyte after fertilization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cortical reaction

To prevent polyspermy, the reaction in the zona pellucida of the oocyte after fertilisation is the cortical reaction.

choices.text: Lung volume increases, thoracic volume increases
Lung volume decreases, thoracic volume increases

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient came with a puncture wound on the left chest wall. Radiological investigations confirmed pneumothorax. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lung volume decreases, thoracic volume increases

In pneumothorax, lung volume is decreased and thoracic volume is increased.

Both lungs and the chest wall (thoracic cage) are elastic structures. Under normal conditions, the elastic tendency of the lungs to collapse is exactly balanced by the elastic tendency of the chest wall to expand.

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TRPV1 channel

Sour taste perception is mediated by the TRPV1 channel (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid 1), which detects food acidity. This cation channel permits the influx of sodium (Na⁺), calcium (Ca²⁺), and magnesium (Mg²⁺) in response to temperature changes and acidic environments, as well as capsaicin.

choices.text: Projection of adjacent fibres to overlap the right somatosensory cortex
Projection of adjacent fibres to overlap the left somatosensory cortex

questions.text: A patient who underwent right limb amputation 2 years back, now presents with severe pain in the limb (Phantom limb pain). On radiological investigations, What is the finding seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Projection of adjacent fibres to overlap the left somatosensory cortex

In the case of phantom limb pain, radiological imaging reveals that adjacent fibers project onto the left somatosensory cortex. This pain arises from cortical plasticity, which allows cortical structures to reorganize after the loss of a limb. The representation of nearby body parts expands into the area previously associated with the amputated limb. This phenomenon, known as cortical plasticity, contributes to phantom limb pain, with the sensory cortical region for the right limb located in the left somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: In a type 2 diabetes mellitus patient, serum insulin levels are found to be raised. He is advised to exercise to improve insulin resistance. Which of the following GLUT will help to improve insulin resistance after exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

GLUT 4

There is an increase in the number of GLUT 4 receptors in response to exercise. This increases the insulin dependent glucose uptake into the cells, contributing to a decrease in insulin resistance.

GLUT-4 is an insulin-dependent GLUT. Other GLUTs are not insulin-sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane.

choices.text: RBC protophyrin is increased in deficiency
Iron excretion is only through skin, gut and urothelial cells
Body cannot compensate if more than 10 RBC/HPF per day is lost in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Ferrireductase convert Fe2+ to Fe 3+

Ferrireductase is an enzyme that reduces Fe³⁺ (ferric iron) to Fe²⁺ (ferrous iron), which is the more absorbable form of iron in the gut. Nearly all iron absorption takes place in the duodenum. Most dietary iron is present as ferric (Fe³⁺), but it is the ferrous (Fe²⁺) form that is effectively absorbed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a chronic tingling sensation in the forearm. A neurological examination is done and appears to be normal. Which of the following receptors are correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pacinian corpuscles-fast vibration

Pacinian corpuscles detect rapid vibrations and are primarily responsible for sensing high-frequency stimuli. The chronic tingling sensation is transmitted by pressure-sensitive Aβ fibers and slower-conducting C fibers. As the most sensitive mechanoreceptors in the somatosensory system, Pacinian corpuscles respond to vibratory stimuli in the range of 30-500 Hz and deep pressure. They are classified as rapidly adapting receptors.

questions.text: What is calculated with the following information?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Maternal Mortality Rate

The given expression is used for calculating the maternal mortality rate. The maternal mortality rate is expressed as the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 women in reproductive age during the same time period”.

questions.text: Every pregnant woman receives a free antenatal check-up on the 9th of each month, along with free medicines and delivery services, including cesarean sections, under the JSSK program. What does JSSK stand for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram

JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram. It is an initiative by the Indian government aimed at reducing maternal and infant mortality.

The provisions of JSSK include:

- Free transport

- Free treatment

- Free drugs and consumables

- Free diagnostics and diet

- Free and cashless delivery

- Free C-Section

- Free provision of blood

questions.text: What is the communication barrier if interpretation of  words are understood in a different manner?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Semantic barrier The communication barrier that occurs when the interpretation of words is understood differently is called a Semantic Barrier. Semantic barriers arise from misunderstandings due to differences in the meaning of words, phrases, or symbols. These barriers can cause confusion and misinterpretation, leading to ineffective communication.

questions.text: 30 young volunteers with previous lifestyle modifications were contributing to drug trial for cholesterol levels based on statin therapy for 9 months. Which of the following tests is performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paired t-test

This study involves a quantitative variable, i.e., blood cholesterol, and compares the before and after results of the same group. Hence, a paired T-test is used.

Tests of significance are used to check for significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

questions.text:
A case-control study is conducted on the association between intake of Vitamin C and the occurrence of respiratory illness. What is the order in which the following steps are conducted?

1 – Measurement of exposure

2- Matching

3-Selecting case and control groups

4- Analysis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

3-2-1-4

The correct order of steps in this case-control study is: Selecting case and control groups (3) -> Matching (2) -> Measurement of exposure (1) -> Analysis (4)

Case-Control Studies are also called retrospective studies. This study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred. They focus on diseases or health problems that have already developed. They are less time-consuming and have no risk of attrition because they do not require follow-up.

questions.text: Which among the following diseases will be the best representation of the submerged portion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Influenza

The best representation of the submerged portion of the iceberg phenomenon would be influenza, as it often has a large number of asymptomatic or mild cases that go undetected, especially in milder seasons.

Tetanus (option A), chickenpox (option C), rabies (option D) and measles are typically acute and severe, with most cases being symptomatic and well-recognized when they occur. They do not show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: What does line B represent in the graph given?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Death rate The line B here represents the death rate. Line A represents the Birth rate Line C represents the Total population

questions.text:
In a sudden onset disaster, the ‘recovery’ phase consists of which of the following?

i)	Preparedness

ii)	Response

iii)	Rehabilitation

iv)	Mitigation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ii and iii only

In disaster management, the recovery phase consists of response and rehabilitation.

Disaster preparedness refers to long-term development activities that strengthen the capacity of a country to manage all kinds of emergencies effectively.

questions.text: A pharmacist randomly selects from three groups of medicines: plant-based, animal-derived, and synthetic. What type of sampling is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stratified sampling

The type of sampling described is stratified random sampling.

In stratified random sampling, the population is divided into distinct subgroups or “strata” (in this case, plant-based, animal-derived, and synthetic medicines). A random sample is then taken from each subgroup.

questions.text: The children in a school underwent a health check-up whose ages were 2,3,4,4,5,6,7,8. What is their median age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

4.5

The median age here is 4.5 years.

In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.

Here: elements: 2,3,4,4,5,6,7,8, therefore median = (4+5)/2= 4.5

Cooling power of air

questions.text: A student was making a presentation with charts but lost titles while editing. What could be the heading for the following chart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Human Development Index

The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development.

questions.text: A mother delivers a baby in a rural area with the assistance of a skilled birth attendant. The attendant cuts the umbilical cord cleanly, ties the ends with new threads, bathes the baby with warm water, wipes the baby’s eyes with a sterile wet cloth from the medial to lateral corner, and then hands the baby to the mother for skin-to-skin contact. Which of these steps is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bathing the child with warm water

The incorrect step is bathing the child with warm water immediately after birth. It is generally recommended to delay bathing in the immediate newborn period to help maintain the baby’s body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

choices.text: Caffeine has no effect, and he can continue taking black coffee
Caffeine causes release of chemical from locus coeruleus that causes awakening
Caffeine has histaminic action in brain that leads to awakening

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of difficulty falling asleep. He consumes black coffee one hour before bed. Which of the following is the role of caffeine in the wakefulness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Caffeine inhibits adenosine receptors, thus leading to awakening

Caffeine promotes wakefulness by inhibiting adenosine receptors, particularly the A2A subtype in the brain. Adenosine, a natural neuromodulator, promotes sleepiness by activating these receptors. By blocking them, caffeine counteracts sedation, enhancing alertness and reducing fatigue.

questions.text: Which of the following SNRI is used in the treatment of ADHD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Reboxetine

The SNRI that can be used for the treatment of ADHD is Reboxetine. Reboxetine, a SNRI has shown potential efficacy in treating ADHD, particularly in patients who do not respond to methylphenidate. Common side effects of reboxetine include drowsiness, sedation, and gastrointestinal issues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a feeling of nervousness and has abdominal pain and diarrhoea. She has had a history of heartburn, and indigestion for the past 25 years. She gives similar complaints in the family of being “tense and nervous”. What other symptoms might you expect to see in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Tingling of extremities

In this case, the patient's nervousness, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and history of digestive issues, along with a family history, may also indicate tingling in the extremities as a symptom of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). According to DSM-5 (and ICD-11) criteria, GAD involves excessive, uncontrollable anxiety and worry about various life aspects lasting at least six months.

questions.text: An elderly patient who is a known case of scleroderma presented with shortness of breath. On examination, her right ventricular pressure was 70-80 mmHg and later on catheterization, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was found to be 35 mmHg. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Endothelin receptor antagonists improves symptoms

In this elderly patient with scleroderma presenting with elevated right ventricular pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, is suggestive of scleroderma/systemic sclerosis(SSc)-associated pulmonary hypertension, and endothelin receptor antagonists improve the symptoms.

Right heart catheterization, the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary hypertension, confirms the condition when the mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) exceeds 20 mmHg. In this elderly patient with scleroderma, elevated right ventricular pressure (70-80 mmHg) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (35 mmHg) Indicate severe pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient with bronchial asthma who has two episodes in the daytime and one episode at night time per week is prescribed albuterol to use as and when required. MDI FEV1 improved from 76% to 83% after taking bronchodilator. What is the further treatment plan?

Add fluticasone propionate 40 mg BD

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient came with chest pain shortness of breath, and pedal edema. JVP showed rapid y descent. On auscultation, he had high high-pitched diastolic sound. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic constrictive pericarditis

The combination of clinical history and rapid y descent in the jugular venous pulse suggests chronic constrictive pericarditis, often caused by tuberculosis in developing countries, as well as viral infections, cardiac surgery, radiation, or autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. This condition results in a rigid, thickened pericardium that restricts ventricular filling, leading to normal filling early in diastole but abrupt cessation when the pericardium's elastic limit is reached, unlike in cardiac tamponade.

NO SPECS criteria is used for this condition

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient comes to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Condition will improve simultaneously with improvement in thyrotoxic state The clinical presentation of a female patient with neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and an enlarged thyroid gland suggests Graves’ disease with thyroid eye disease (TED). TED does not improve at the same time as the hyperthyroid state. Graves’ disease leads to hyperthyroidism due to thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) produced by lymphocytes, which stimulates the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 56-year-old presented with fever chills & cough with sputum. Blood pressure was measured to be 150/88mmhg, pulse rate 110bpm and respiratory rate-18, spo2-88% at room air. An X-ray was done and shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Community acquired pneumonia

The clinical vignette describes a case of community- acquired pneumonia. The findings of fever, chills, cough with expectoration, and chest X-ray findings of lobar involvement support the diagnosis.

Clinical features include acute onset fever, cough (with or without sputum production), and shortness of breath. In some cases, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxemia, or increased work of breathing may be present on physical examination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with fatigue and hemoptysis. His current hemoglobin is 8g/dL (previous hemoglobin one week ago was 12g/dL). His bronchoalveolar lavage is reddish and his serum creatinine was 1.7mg/dL. He is diagnosed with ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis. Biopsy of the kidney revealed pauci-immune deposits and the absence of granulomas. Which of the following conditions is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Microscopic polyangiitis

The clinical scenario is indicative of microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), which is distinguished from other forms of ANCA-associated vasculitis by the absence of granulomatous inflammation. ANCA-associated vasculitis is classified into three types:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, previously Wegener granulomatosis)

•	Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)

•	Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss syndrome)

•	Both GPA and MPA share necrotizing vasculitis as a key histological feature, commonly seen in kidney biopsies.

questions.text: A patient with an acute exacerbation of COPD required mechanical ventilation and experienced a consistent drop in oxygen saturation. Auscultation revealed vesicular breath sounds on the right side. Based on the chest radiography findings, what would you expect to hear on auscultation of the left side?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Absent breath sounds

Absent breath sounds on the left side are expected in this case of left pneumothorax.

A pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, causing lung collapse and preventing normal lung expansion, which leads to absent or diminished breath sounds over the affected area. In patients with COPD, particularly during an acute exacerbation, the already weakened and hyperinflated lung tissue can rupture, leading to a pneumothorax. This is a serious complication, especially when mechanical ventilation is required, as the pressure from the ventilator can exacerbate the pneumothorax.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with partial compensated respiratory alkolosis with high anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.text: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report: pH = 7.3, pCO2=16mmHg, HCO3—6.3mmol/L, Na+-135, K+- 4.5 CI-113.7, lactate was normal. Which of the following options correctly describes the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metabolic acidosis with partial compensated respiratory alkolosis with high anion gap The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis with partially compensated respiratory alkalosis with high anion gap. It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This can be understood by the following calculation: Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.3 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis Step 2: HCO3 is 6.3 mmol/L (Normal HCO3-22-30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3 levels decrease. Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis. Step 3: Calculate the anion gap. Anion gap = Na+(CI+HCO3-) 135-(113.7 +6.3) = 15, which is a high anion gap (normal anion gap is between 6-12 mEq/L) Step 4: As per Winter’s formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can be calculated using, PCO₂ =(1.5 x [HCO3]) +8 ± 2 In this case, Expected pCO2 = (1.5 x [6.3]) +8 ± 2 = 17.5 ± 2 = 15.45-19.45 mmHg The pCO2 in this patient is 16 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis contributing to reduced pCO2.

questions.text: Match the following ECG waves with condition: atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, SVT, ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1-ii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-iii

The matched option is option A, i.e., 1-ii, 2-i, 3-iv, 4-iii. Atrial flutter rhythm is regular. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

Atrial fibrillation rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (PSVT) ECG shows narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with an absent P wave. Ventricular tachycardia ECG changes include wide QRS complexes, absence of P waves, and ventriculoatrial dissociation.

It can be broadly classified as sustained VT or non-sustained VT. Nonsustained VT has QRS complexes lasting <30 seconds while sustained VT lasts for >30 seconds.

In monomorphic VT, all QRS complexes look the same. Polymorphic VT has QRS complexes varying in shape or direction in the same lead.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with lethargy and tiredness. On examination, he has perioral hyperpigmentation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and his heart rate is 110 beats/minute. Laboratory investigations revealed Na+ of 125mEq/L and K+ of 5.5mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hydrocortisone + Fludrocortisone

This clinical scenario indicates primary adrenal insufficiency (Addisonian crisis), for which IV hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are the most appropriate treatments. Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal disease), secondary (due to pituitary issues affecting ACTH), or tertiary (due to hypothalamic problems affecting CRH). Autoimmune adrenalitis is the leading cause of primary adrenal insufficiency globally, while tuberculosis is the most common cause in India.

questions.text: A young woman comes with weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors. She has exophthalmos on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Graves disease Based on the clinical findings the most likely diagnosis is Graves’ disease. The hyperthyroidism of Graves’ disease is caused by thyroid- stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) that are synthesized in the thyroid gland as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes. TSI cause stimulation of the thyroid gland causing features of hyperthyroidism in the presence of low TSH levels.

choices.text: Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluroquinolones
Mutation only to INH A and kat G gene

questions.text: For MDR-RR TB, what is the indication of short course bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluroquinolones

Resistance to rifampicin and sensitivity to fluoroquinolones is an indication of a short course of bedaquiline. A shorter MDR-TB regimen of 6 months, BPaLM, is the treatment of choice for MDR/RR TB as per the latest WHO guidelines.

A longer TB regimen has to be used instead of the shorter MDR TB regimen if:

-	XDR TB is suspected 

-	Pregnancy and lactation (Pretomanid is not safe in pregnancy or breastfeeding)

-	Patients aged < 14 years

-	Resistance to the components of BPaLM regimen

questions.text: In a patient with type 1 diabetes with 3rd stage beta cell damage, which of the following situations is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Autoimmune positive with dysglycemia

In type 1 diabetes mellitus, autoimmune positivity with dysglycemia indicates Stage 3, where clinical diabetes has become evident. This advanced stage is characterized by significant beta cell destruction and insulin deficiency, resulting in symptomatic diabetes.
Individuals with a genetic predisposition are exposed to a trigger that initiates an autoimmune process, leading to the production of islet autoantibodies and a progressive decline in beta cell function.

choices.text: IV thiamine followed by dextrose infusion
Injection vitamin K followed by dextrose infusion

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented to the emergency in an unconscious state. Relatives stated that he had a similar episode of binge drinking one week back. On examination, his glucose was 49mg/dl. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV thiamine followed by dextrose infusion The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke’s encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke’s encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids like IV dextrose.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitations. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease, ECG of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Hyperkalemia

The given clinical presentation and the tall T waves on ECG indicate hyperkalemia, which is commonly seen in a patient with chronic kidney disease.

Workload has nothing to do with myocardial 02 consumption
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure than aortic valve

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and angina episodes. On workup, she is found to have aortic stenosis. Which of the following findings favor the diagnosis of aortic stenosis over aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increase in myocardial 02 consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

In evaluating the case of a 50-year-old female presenting with dyspnea and angina episodes, it is essential to differentiate between aortic stenosis (AS) and aortic regurgitation (AR). The key factor to consider in aortic stenosis(AS) is that increased myocardial oxygen consumption is more closely associated with increased pressure work rather than increased volume.
