questions.text: A patient presented with fatigue and tingling sensation in the arms, weight loss and h/o polyuria. The following findings were detected on bone marrow biopsy. What is probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Multiple myeloma

The clinical scenario and marrow aspirate with plasma cells indicate multiple myeloma. Symptoms such as fatigue, tingling in the arms, weight loss, and polyuria are due to hypercalcemia. Plasma cell dyscrasias involve B-cell proliferations with neoplastic plasma cells that produce a monoclonal immunoglobulin or fragment. Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell neoplasm marked by monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in serum and urine, primarily affecting older adults, with peak incidence between ages 65 and 70.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dyspnea and chest pain. The pleural fluid analysis shows pleural protein/ serum protein > 0.5, and pleural LDH/ serum LDH > 0.4. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tuberculosis

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an exudative pleural effusion according to Light’s criteria. Among the given options, tuberculosis can lead to exudative pleural effusion.

In any patient diagnosed with a pleural effusion, an effort should be made to find the cause. This requires a diagnostic thoracocentesis and analysis of the pleural fluid in terms of whether it is a transudate or an exudate based on Light’s criteria:

1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5

2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6

3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds the upper limit of normal for serum

questions.text: An adolescent presented with fever, purpura on the thigh, swelling of the right knee and left ankle, and abnormal "Mid" diastolic murmur in the cardiac apical area. He was seronegative for rheumatoid factor. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute rheumatic fever

The adolescent's symptoms—fever, purpura, joint swelling (right knee and left ankle), and abnormal heart sounds—suggest acute rheumatic fever (ARF). ARF is an inflammatory condition that can follow a Group A Streptococcal infection, like strep throat. It primarily affects the heart, joints, skin, and central nervous system. Symptoms include fever, migratory arthritis, and carditis, with abnormal heart sounds indicating potential mitral valve involvement. Skin manifestations, such as purpura, may also occur.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of easy fatiguability, anaemia, hyperpigmentation of knuckles, oral mucosa, palm and hands, and tachycardia. The blood pressure of the patient is 80/60 mm Hg and Na+ 130mmHg. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary adrenal insufficiency

The clinical presentation of easy fatigue, skin hyperpigmentation, low blood pressure, and hyponatremia suggests primary adrenal insufficiency, or Addison’s disease. This condition is often caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and can lead to other autoimmune disorders, including vitiligo, premature ovarian failure, and autoimmune thyroid disease. Additionally, Addison’s disease may result from adrenal gland damage due to infections like tuberculosis, hemorrhage (as seen in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome), or infiltration.

questions.text: A female presents with choreo-athetoid movements, dysarthria, and dystonia with the given finding. Which of the following is the best investigation to confirm the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatic copper content

The clinical scenario, combined with the image of a Kayser-Fleischer ring, indicates Wilson's disease. To confirm the diagnosis, measuring hepatic copper content is the most effective method. Key diagnostic criteria for Wilson's disease include elevated 24-hour urinary copper excretion, which serves as the most specific screening test, and increased hepatic copper levels, recognized as the most sensitive and accurate test. Additionally, a reduction in serum ceruloplasmin and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings support the diagnosis. Genetic testing for mutations in the ATP7B gene can also be utilized for confirmation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old footballer collapsed on the field and could not be revived. An autopsy was conducted and on cardiac biopsy, the left ventricle was hypertrophied. Identify the possible cause for the same.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

The given clinical scenario and autopsy findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The image given is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and extreme hypertrophy as seen in HCM.

HCM is the leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. It is defined as left ventricular hypertrophy of >15mm an ECHO. The left ventricular myocardium is poorly compliant. This leads to abnormal diastolic filling and intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction, i.e., primarily diastolic dysfunction

questions.text: A male presented with discharge as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Fistula in ano

The diagnosis, considering the purulent discharge shown in the image, is a fistula in ano.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is a perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn’s disease.

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency department after RTA with complaints of chest pain and breathing difficulty. An X-ray was done and is given below. What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paradoxical

The breathing pattern observed in this patient with X-ray evidence of contiguous right rib fractures suggests paradoxical respiration, characteristic of flail chest. This condition typically results from blunt trauma causing three or more rib fractures in two or more locations, leading to a segment of the chest wall moving independently. Diagnosis is made clinically by noting that the affected area moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Patients are at increased risk for pneumothorax and hemothorax, with a CT scan being the gold standard for evaluation.

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-month-old male child to the hospital, who is currently unable to pass urine. A similar issue was reported 15 days ago. The catheter could be passed without difficulty. The image of the micturating cystourethrogram is given below. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Destruction of valves

The micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) image shows a dilated prostatic urethra with transverse filling defects indicative of posterior urethral valves. The best management is valve destruction. These valves are the leading cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children and consist of membranes with a small slit, located just distal to the verumontanum, obstructing urinary flow.

questions.text: What is the condition seen here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oesophageal varices

The given endoscopic image of a patient suggests esophageal varices.

Esophageal varices are tortuous dilated veins within the mucosa and submucosa of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach. Variceal hemorrhage is an emergency that can be treated medically by inducing splanchnic vasoconstriction or endoscopically by sclerotherapy, balloon tamponade, or variceal ligation.

questions.text: The baby was born with this deformity. What is the earliest age to correct this defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

6 months

The earliest age to correct bilateral cleft lip and palate in a child is 6 months. Cleft lip repair is typically performed between 3-6 months, 
while palate repair occurs between 6-12 months. In this case, the best option is 6 months for palatal repair. Cleft lip results from the failure of fusion between the maxillary and medial nasal prominences, varying from a small notch to a double cleft. This condition often leads to underdevelopment of the maxilla near the incisors. The Millard technique for cleft lip repair involves rotating local nasolabial flaps.

questions.text: A patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dysuria and sterile pyuria. The cystoscopy image of the patient is provided below. Based on the patient’s history and the cystoscopic findings, which of the following conditions is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Golf hole ureter

The cystoscopic examination reveals a "golf hole ureter," which is commonly linked to genitourinary tuberculosis (TB). This condition arises from the spread of the bacteria through the bloodstream, making it a secondary form of TB. It may result from either reinfection or the reactivation of previous infections. Genitourinary TB can impact various structures, including the kidneys, ureters, bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, epididymis, and vas deferens.

questions.text: What instrument is required for the following procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cystourethroscope

The instrument required for placing the Double J stent (DJ stent), as shown in the radiograph is a cystourethroscope.
Cystourethroscopy allows for the examination and access of the bladder and urethra, which is crucial for guiding the DJ stent from the bladder into the ureter. This procedure involves inserting a flexible or rigid endoscope through the urethra and into the bladder, where the stent can be manoeuvred into the ureter.

questions.text: A patient with a history of umbilical swelling. Initially asymptomatic for many years, now complains of pain over the swelling. The swelling was reducible initially but is now non-reducible. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Umbilectomy with herniorrhaphy

The recommended treatment for this patient with a painful, non-reducible umbilical hernia is umbilical herniorrhaphy combined with umbiliectomy. An umbilical hernia occurs when a defect in the umbilical area allows abdominal contents to bulge out. In adults, these hernias typically present as swelling near the umbilicus that can become painful and irreducible. Factors like obesity, pregnancy, and liver cirrhosis with ascites can increase the risk of complications.

questions.text: A baby was brought In with complaints of intermittent faeculent discharge from the umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ileal diverticulum Feculent discharge from the umbilicus indicates a vitelline fistula, resulting from a persistent vitellointestinal duct or ileal diverticulum. The clinical image suggests a congenital umbilical anomaly, such as a patent urachus, urachal cyst, or vitelline cyst. The next best step is an abdominal ultrasound to determine if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or a fistula, and to assess its connections.

questions.text: A patient presents with renal colic and recurrent urinary tract infections. A CT scan reveals no significant findings. The patient undergoes a percutaneous nephrolithotomy and his urine analysis is as shown. Based on the clinical presentation and the urine analysis findings, what are these crystals made up of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cystine

The image displays a hexagonal crystal, indicative of cystine stones, which frequently recur in patients with cystinuria. Cystinuria is the most common genetic disorder affecting amino acid transport, caused by a defective transporter in the kidney's proximal tubules. This results in the excretion of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine (collectively known as COLA). The condition leads to cystine stone formation and renal colic, with oral hydration being the primary treatment.

questions.text: What is the treatment plan for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Split thickness skin grafting

The clinical image suggests partial thickness burns, and the appropriate treatment is split-thickness skin grafting. Split-thickness skin grafts (Thiersch grafts) include the epidermis and part of the dermis. A graft with less dermis results in reduced primary contraction (shrinkage before grafting) and increased secondary contraction (shrinkage during healing). A Humby knife is used for harvesting these grafts.

questions.text:
A patient with oral cancer underwent radical surgery and PMMC flap reconstruction as shown. What is the most important indicator for considering adjuvant radiotherapy in this patient?

(PMMC flap Pectoralis Major Myocutaneous flap)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Extra nodal extension The most important indicator for considering adjuvant radiotherapy in this patient is extranodal extension (ENE). For patients with oral cavity cancer, ENE is a key indicator for adjuvant radiotherapy. Adjuvant therapy, typically involving external beam radiotherapy, is recommended based on pathological features such as ENE, close margins (1-4.9 mm), or involved margins (1 mm), lymphovascular invasion (LVI), and perineural invasion (PNI).

questions.text: Identify the stage of bed sore in the sacral region.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stage 4

The image depicts a stage 4 pressure sore, characterized by extensive tissue damage, including muscle involvement. Pressure sores, also known as bed sores or pressure ulcers, result from prolonged pressure that causes tissue necrosis. Common sites include the ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, lateral malleolus, and occiput. Paraplegic individuals, the elderly, and severely ill patients are at greater risk for developing these sores.

questions.text: Based on the constituents, identify the fluid given to post-operative patients.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ringer lactate

The fluid shown in the image is ringer lactate or Hartmann’s solution.

Ringer lactate, or Hartmann’s solution, is a crystalloid made up of sodium 131 mEq, chloride 112 mEq, potassium 5 mEq, bicarbonate (as lactate) 29 mEq, and 2 mEq of calcium. It is devoid of glucose.

It is useful in the following conditions:

- Correction of severe hypovolemia

- Metabolic acidosis

- Postoperative period, burns, diarrhoea

- Correction of hypokalemia

- Diabetic ketoacidosis.

choices.text: Neo adjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery

questions.text: A female patient presented with a breast mass, as shown in the image below, with concomitant liver metastasis. What is the recommended management. Plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Simple mastectomy

According to the TNM staging system, this patient has Stage IV breast cancer due to the presence of distant metastasis (liver) and thereby the recommended management plan is simple mastectomy, as a palliative measure.

choices.text: Penectomy + Superficial inguinal lymph node dissection

questions.text: An elderly male who presented with the following lesion as shown, is diagnosed with stage T3 carcinoma with no clinically palpable inguinal lymph nodes. What is the management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Penectomy + Superficial inguinal lymph node dissection

The most appropriate management for this patient with stage T3 carcinoma of the penis with no clinically palpable inguinal lymph nodes is penectomy with superficial inguinal lymph node dissection.

questions.text: The most commonly occurring complication of TPN in a sepsis patient in ICU:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hyperglycemia

The most commonly occurring complication of TPN in a sepsis patient in the ICU is hyperglycemia.

questions.text:
A CT scan of a patient with a hydatid cyst is shown below. What is the type of hydatid cyst as per the Gharbi classification?

CT-Computed Tomography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type 2

The given CT scan showing the hydatid cyst with detached membranes (Water Lily sign) is classified as CE-3 according to the WHO classification and Type 2 according to the Gharbi classification.

choices.text: Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose

questions.text: If a tumor compresses the structures passing through the opening marked in the given image, which of the following sensations would be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose

The superior orbital fissure is a vital opening in the skull that transmits several important structures, including the frontal and nasociliary nerves, branches of the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1). A tumor compressing these nerves would impair sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose.

questions.text: An absent gag reflex can result from injury to which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

IX and X

An absent gag reflex can result from injury to the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) and the vagus nerve (X).

The afferent nerve for the gag reflex is the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent nerve consists of both the glossopharyngeal (to the stylopharyngeus muscle) and vagus. Both these nerves pass through the jugular foramen and damage to them may be the cause for loss of gag reflex.

questions.text: A chronic tobacco consumer went to the dental clinic with bleeding lesions on his tongue and was diagnosed with carcinoma of the tongue. Which of the following papillae, which do not have taste buds, is least likely to be involved in such a cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Filiform

Filiform papillae, found on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, are small cylindrical or conical projections that do not contain taste buds. They are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: What is the outer covering of the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amnion

The diagnosis is omphalocele, a midline abdominal wall defect where bowel and other organs protrude through the umbilicus, covered by peritoneum and amnion. The umbilical cord inserts directly into the sac, aiding identification. This defect occurs when the physiological hernia fails to return to the body cavity by the 11th week of gestation.

questions.text: Which artery is used for arteriovenous shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis, and is located behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendocalcaneus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior tibial artery

The posterior tibial artery, located behind the medial malleolus and about 2.5 cm in front of the tendocalcaneus, is a potential site for creating an AV fistula with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis. While suitable for optimal access and blood flow, it is not commonly used in practice.

questions.text: A child presents with orangish hue skin with rough and scaly skin as shown in the image. On histopathological examination, orthokeratosis and parakeratosis are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pityriasis rubra pilaris

The image shows prominent erythema and scale on the palms of the hands and wrists with marked orange-yellow palmoplantar keratoderma which is a feature of pityriasis rubra pilaris.

choices.text: Lepromatous leprosy with dermal test positive
Tuberculoid leprosy with dermal test positive
Lepromatous leprosy with dermal test negative
Erythema nodosum leprosum with negative skin test

questions.text: A patient presented with a slight loss of sensation along the ulnar nerve and a solitary nodule in the forearm. Intradermal antigen was injected. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tuberculoid leprosy with dermal test positive

The patient’s slight loss of sensation along the ulnar nerve, solitary forearm nodule, and histopathology showing well- defined granulomas indicate tuberculoid leprosy with a dermal test positive.

In tuberculoid leprosy, dermal granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are seen. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone. It also shows high positivity of the lepromin skin (dermal) test.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the” box sign”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Morphea

The “box sign” is associated with morphea, also known as localized scleroderma

Morphea is a condition characterized by localized skin sclerosis and fibrosis due to increased collagen deposition. This can lead to well-defined, box-like patches of thickened, hardened skin. The “box sign” refers to the sharp, boxy edges of these lesions, which can vary in depth and extent, sometimes involving deeper tissues such as muscle and bone.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with painful vesicular lesions over the genital area. He has a history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Genital Herpes

The most likely diagnosis for this patient with painful vesicular lesions over the genital area is genital herpes.

The diagnosis of genital herpes is suggested by the presence of painful, multiple vesicular ulcers clustered on the genitalia, along with inguinal lymphadenopathy. These symptoms are indicative of an infection caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2), which is the primary cause of genital herpes.

choices.text: A- Apocrine sweat gland; B- Eccrine sweat gland, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Erector pili muscle
A- Eccrine sweat gland; B- Apocrine sweat gland; C- Sebaceous gland, D- Erector pili muscle
A- Sebaceous gland, B- Apocrine sweat gland, C- Eccrine sweat gland: D- Erector pili muscle
A- Eccrine sweat gland; B- Sebaceous gland; C- Apocrine sweat gland; D- Erector pili muscle

questions.text: Match the structures shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A- Eccrine sweat gland; B- Apocrine sweat gland; C- Sebaceous gland, D- Erector pili muscle

The correctly matched option (B)- A- Eccrine sweat gland; B- Apocrine sweat gland; C- Sebaceous gland; D- Erector pili muscle.
Human skin contains various structures, including sweat and sebaceous glands. Eccrine sweat glands, which are crucial for temperature regulation, are distributed across most of the body and are identified early in fetal development. These glands have a coiled secretory portion in the lower dermis and a duct that opens directly onto the skin surface. They are most concentrated on the palms, soles, and forehead

Apocrine sweat glands, found in areas like the axillae, genital, and mammary regions, differ from eccrine glands in that they release secretion via decapitation, where parts of the cell pinch off. They are connected to hair follicles and have a larger lumen compared to eccrine glands. Their primary function remains unclear, and they have a lower secretory output.

Sebaceous glands secrete sebum, providing skin lubrication and waterproofing. These glands are associated with hair follicles and are absent in non-hairy skin.

The erector pili muscle, a smooth muscle bundle, extends from the dermis to the follicle wall and is involved in hair erection

questions.text: An adult male presented with asymptomatic macules over the chest, moist grey, perianal lesions, and findings on the scalp as shown. What is the most likely causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Treponema pallidum

The most likely causative organism for this condition is Treponema pallidum, which caused the asymptomatic macules on the chest, moist grey, perianal lesions, and moth- eaten pattern alopecia seen in secondary syphilis.

The causative organism for this condition is Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacterium. In secondary syphilis, the macular or roseolar rash is often the earliest sign, which may fade, leaving hypopigmented areas around the neck, known as leucoderma syphiliticum or “necklace of Venus.” This stage also features a papular rash that can appear on the palms and soles.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is responsible for ptosis in horner’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Muller’s muscle

Ptosis in Horner’s syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller’s muscle. Muller’s muscle(superior tarsal muscle) maintains the elevation of the upper eyelid. It is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system.

Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated in cases having mild ptosis(<2 mm) and good levator function. In this surgery, the upper tarsal border along with its attached Muller’s muscle and conjunctiva are resected.

questions.text: An 11-year-old presented with the following growth in the eye as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Limbal dermoid

The image shows the presence of a limbal dermoid.

Limbal Dermoid is a choristoma (a mass of histologically normal tissue in an abnormal location). It consists of collagenous tissue containing dermal elements and covered by stratified squamous epithelium. Limbal dermoid present in early childhood as a subconjunctival mass in the infratemporal limbus. Treatment is indicated for chronic irritation, amblyopia, vision impairment and corneal dellen formation. Small dermoids can be excised, larger lesions may need lamellar keratosclerectomy.

questions.text: Patient undergoes lens implantation folllowing which there’s worsening of vision after 1 year. Slit lamp examination finding is shown in the image below. Identify the complication.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Posterior subcapsular cataract

The given clinical vignette supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls which is a type of posterior subcapsular cataract (after cataract).

Posterior subcapsular cataracts occur mainly due to ageing, other causes include the use of topical steroids, trauma, excessive consumption of alcohol, and exposure to ionizing radiation. Visual impairment is more during the day or exposure to bright light as the pupil constricts which blocks light rays.

questions.text: Identify the perimetry finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Blind spot enlargement

The perimetry image in the question above shows blind spot enlargement.

Blind spot enlargement is a rare finding in the visual field examination. The most common cause of blind spot enlargement is Idiopathic intracranial hypertension. Blind spot enlargement occurs due to displacement of the peripapillary retina and refractive changes due to significant optic nerve head swelling. Other common causes of blind spot enlargement are Syphilis, West Nile virus, or Rubella vaccination

questions.text: A patient undergoes worth's four-dot test. The results are as shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Right suppression The given image with 3 green dots likely suggests that the patient is suffering from right suppression.

Procedure:
• The patient wears red-green goggles
(red lens over one eye, usually the right, and green lens over the left). >
• A target with four lights (one red, two green, and one white) is presented at both near (33 cm) and far (6 m) distances.
• The patient is asked to describe what they see. →
Interpreting the Results:
• Normal Binocular Vision: With both eyes open, a patient with normal binocular vision will see four lights (one red, two green, and one white). → Suppression: If one eye is suppressing, the patient may see only three lights (red, two green, or green, white, and red). →
• Diplopia (Double Vision): If the patient
does not fuse the images of the two eyes and sees double, they will see five lights.

questions.text: A 20-year-old presented with gradual loss of vision at night and a fundoscopy image is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Retinitis pigmentosa

The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules along with gradual loss of vision which implies that it is case of retinitis pigmentosa (RP).

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X- linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

questions.text: A patient met with road traffic accident and complained of severe back ache. The X-ray is shown below. What fracture does the patient have?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chance fracture The X-ray reveals a vertebral fracture with a horizontal line through the vertebra, indicating a Chance fracture. Also known as a seat-belt or jack-knife injury, this fracture typically occurs in the upper lumbar spine during motor vehicle collisions involving a lap seat belt without a shoulder harness. Sudden deceleration leads to flexion and posterior distraction of the spine, causing the mid-lumbar region to bend like a jack-knife around an axis in front of the vertebral column.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy complains of fever and pain in the lower limb. There is a localised rise of temperature and tenderness in the region shown in the radiograph. ESR is raised. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ewing’s sarcoma The clinical features and radiograph showing onion peel type of periosteal reaction point towards a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing’s sarcoma is a malignant tumour that occurs more frequently in males, typically between 10 and 20 years of age and has a diaphyseal long-bone location. The femur is the most common long-bone site, followed by the tibia, humerus and fibula. Ewing’s sarcoma is believed to arise from mesenchymal stem cells in the bone marrow.

questions.text: A child sustained an injury as shown in the below radiograph. What is the classification used and the grade used for this type of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gartland’s classification-type III

The given clinical features and X-ray image are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus (extension type) and Gartland classification is used in this case. The extension type fracture which is displaced with no intact posterior cortex is type 3 as per this classification.

Gartland classification (in children):

Type I: Undisplaced

Type II: Displaced but posterior cortex is intact

Type III: Displaced but no intact posterior cortex and distal fragment could be either displaced:

- Posteromedial

- Posterolateral

questions.text: A patient sustained a fracture of the base of the fifth metatarsal in the right foot. He was advised below knee pop cast. How long should the cast be put?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

6-8 weeks

The given X-ray indicates a Jones fracture. Conservative management involves a short-leg non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks.
A Jones fracture is typically caused by forced inversion of the foot, such as during a pothole injury, leading to the avulsion of the base of the fifth metatarsal. This injury is due to the pull of the peroneus brevis tendon or the lateral band of the plantar fascia, which inserts onto the base of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a patient with an intertrochanteric fracture of the femur was treated with the implant shown below. Identify the implant.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dynamic hip screw

The above radiograph shows an extramedullary implant called a dynamic hip screw.
Intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by:

-	Extramedullary implants – dynamic hip screw 

-	Intramedullary implants – proximal femoral nail and gamma nail.

Dynamic hip screws are used in undisplaced intertrochanteric fractures, whereas proximal femoral nails are used in displaced intertrochanteric fractures.

questions.text: A young woman, following an intense workout involving heavy weight lifting, presents with lower back pain radiating to her right hip and extending down to her right ankle. MRI shows the following finding. Based on the location and radiation of her pain, which of the following nerve roots is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

L5

Based on the clinical presentation of lower back pain radiating to the right hip and ankle, along with an MRI showing L4-L5 disc prolapse, the likely nerve root involved is L5. In a typical L4-L5 disc herniation, the L5 nerve root is most commonly compressed.

questions.text: A child with rickets not responding to treatment is being evaluated. Investigations show a serum calcium level of 9 mg/dL, low phosphate level of 2 mg/dL, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and normal parathyroid hormone levels with normal arterial blood gas levels. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypophosphatemic rickets

The given scenario indicates the diagnosis of hypophosphatemic rickets because of the following features:

- normal calcium levels (Normal: 9-11 mg/dL) 

– normal parathyroid hormone levels 

– decreased phosphate (Normal: 2.5-4.3 mg/dL)

- elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase (Normal: 33-96 U/L)

- normal arterial blood gas levels

questions.text: What is this type of amputation called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Below knee amputation

The given image shows below-knee amputation.

By retaining the knee joint, a below-knee amputation allows for better mobility and function compared to an above-knee amputation. After surgery, patients can usually be fitted with a prosthetic limb, enabling them to walk with a relatively normal gait.

questions.text: Which condition is inherited according to the given pedigree?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

The given pedigree chart points towards an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance and among the options provided Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is inherited via this mode. A Triad of micro-thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections points towards Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

choices.text: VWD type 3 has severely low levels of VWF
VWD type 1 is the most severe disease in children
VWD type 3 is the most severe disease in children
VWD type 2 is associated with moderate bleeding tendency

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about vWD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

VWD type 1 is the most severe disease in children Von Willebrand disease type 1 is not the most severe disease in children. On the other hand, it has been found that It is VWD type 3 which is the most severe.

questions.text: A patient with COPD presented with ARDS symptoms. What is the role of IL-8 in inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Recuritement of neutrophils

IL-8 (CXCL8) is secreted by activated macrophages and endothelial cells which causes activation and recruitment of neutrophils.

Once leukocytes have exited the circulation, they move towards the inciting stimulus by chemotaxis.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly and WBC count >50,000/mm3. Which of the following genes is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

t (9:22)

The clinical scenario of abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly, a TLC of > 50,000/mm³ points toward the diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) which results from reciprocal translocation t(9:22) forming the BCR- ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with weight loss, hemoptysis and TTF-1 positivity. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Adenocarcinoma

The clinical scenario cough, hemoptysis, weight loss with image showing immunohistochemical marker thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) positivity is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery as compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller in size. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with flank pain and hematuria. The histology slide of the patient is provided. Based on the clinical presentation and histological findings, which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma The given histological image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. It can be identified by the presence of pale eosinophilic cells arranged in the form of solid sheets with some cells having a perinuclear halo.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea along with skin eruptions. He gives the history of similar episodes in the past. After switching to gluten free diet his symptoms resolved. Which marker is useful in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti tissue transglutaminase antibody

The given scenario of vomiting, diarrhoea, skin eruptions and resolving symptoms with gluten free diet along with crypt hperplasia, villous atrophy and intra epithelial lymphocyte as seen in histopathology are suggestive of celiac disease. Anti tissue transglutaminase antibody will help in diagnosing this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following processes is mediated by CRISPR CAS-9 technology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Gene editing

CRISPR-Cas9 is a gene editing tool derived from the bacterial immune system that allows for precise modifications of DNA. It utilizes Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) transcribed into RNA, which guides the Cas9 enzyme to a specific DNA sequence. Cas9 then creates a double-stranded break in the DNA, enabling targeted gene editing with the help of an artificial guide RNA.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is appropriate for reversing vecuronium when renal function tests are normal?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sugammadex Sugammadex is used for immediate reversal of vecuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade/relaxant in the given scenario. Sugammadex is a modified y-cyclodextrin and the first selective relaxant-binding agent based on an encapsulating principle for the inactivation of nondepolarising neuromuscular blocking drugs mainly rocuronium and vecuronium. This principle of complex formation of sugammadex and rocuronium or vecuronium in a 1:1 ratio occurs at all levels of neuromuscular blockade resulting in a more fast-acting pharmacologic reversal when compared with anticholinesterase drugs like neostigmine.

questions.text: A COPD patient with a history of smoking presents with respiratory symptoms. High resolution CT showed panacinar emphysema. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alpha-1 antitrypsin Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is associated with panacinar emphysema. Panacinar or panlobular emphysema is associated with alpha1 antitrypsin (alpha1 AT) deficiency. It is exacerbated by smoking. Panacinar occurs more commonly in lower zones and the anterior margins of the lung. In this type, the acini from respiratory bronchiole to terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented with low Hb, platelet count of 25000/mm3, raised PT and aPTT. A peripheral smear is given. Which of the following fusion genes is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

PML RARA

The presence of numerous Auer rods and lab findings indicating DIC suggest acute myeloid leukemia M3, or acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). This condition is linked to the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the translocation t(15;17). Patients typically present with fever, fatigue, and weight loss, along with signs of anemia (pallor) and thrombocytopenia (easy bruising) due to the rapid destruction of red blood cell and platelet precursors in the bone marrow.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child comes with cervical lymphadenopathy. Lymph node biopsy shows CD 10 +, CD 19+, CD 20+, CD 5, CD 23-, and Tdt negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Burkitt lymphoma The clinical presentation of a child with a cervical lymph node positive for CD 10, 19, and 20, but negative for CD 5, 23, and TdT, coupled with histopathology showing tumor cells in a diffuse monotonous pattern with clumped chromatin and basophilic cytoplasm containing lipid vacuoles, suggests a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

questions.text: Identify the disease with the chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prader Willi syndrome

Paternal deletion of 15q12 is associated with Prader-Willi syndrome, a non-Mendelian disorder stemming from genomic imprinting. This syndrome arises from the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome, combined with the silencing of corresponding genes on the maternal chromosome. Key features include intellectual disability, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and distinctive facial characteristics such as a small upturned nose, narrow bifrontal distance, and thin upper lip.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient comes with complaints of left flank pain, hematuria, weight loss, headache, nausea, and convulsions. A family history of brain tumours and kidney tumours is present. MRI showed a cerebellar mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome

The clinical presentation of left flank pain, hematuria, weight loss, headache, nausea, and convulsions, along with a family history of brain and kidney tumors, suggests Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL). VHL is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and predisposes individuals to various neoplasms, particularly cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas. It also leads to hundreds of bilateral renal cysts and clear cell carcinomas in 40% to 60% of cases. Patients with VHL have a germline mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3p.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common mutation associated with the microscopy image of the thyroid shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

BRAF V600E

The most common mutation associated with the microscopy image which shows the Orphan Annie eye nuclei which is characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the BRAF V600E mutation.

questions.text: Which of the following stain can be used for laryngeal mass seen during laryngoscopic examination?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Supra vital Laryngoscopic image shows growth over the vocal cords; supravital stain is used to detect laryngeal mass seen during laryngoscopic examination. In the larynx, it is difficult to identify carcinoma in situ, early infiltrating carcinoma, and the exact margins of an established carcinoma. However, it has been found that the use of toluidine blue as a supravital stain during direct laryngoscopy is a reliable adjunct to the early and precise diagnosis of carcinoma of the larynx.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department with epistaxis and a nasal mass. What is the investigation of choice to evaluate his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CECT PNS and nose In a patient with a nasal mass and epistaxis, nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is suspected. A CECT of the PNS and nose can help evaluate this condition, particularly showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral or Holman-Miller sign), indicative of angiofibroma.

choices.text: Right saccade with right side movement
Left saccade with right side movement
Right saccade with left side movement
Left saccade with left side movement

questions.text: A female patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and a sensation of objects moving around her. She is diagnosed with left vestibular neuritis. Her head impulse test is positive. What is the correct finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right saccade with left side movement In left vestibular neuritis, the head impulse test will reveal a right saccade when the head is turned to the left. This test evaluates the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), and an abnormal result indicates impaired VOR on the affected side, resulting in saccades. Saccades are quick, jerky eye movements that occur as the eyes attempt to realign with the intended point of focus.

choices.text: Auriculotemporal nerve; B – Greater auricular nerve; C-Facial and Vagus nerve
A-Greater auricular nerve; B- Auriculotemporal nerve; C-Facial and Vagus nerve
A-Greater auricular nerve; B – Facial and Vagus nerve; C-Auriculotemporal nerve
A-Facial and Vagus nerve; B – Greater auricular nerve; C-Auriculotemporal nerve

questions.text: Match the following with the nerve supply of external ear.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Auriculotemporal nerve; B – Greater auricular nerve; C-Facial and Vagus nerve

The correct associations regarding the nerve supply to the pinna are as follows: Greater auricular nerve (A): Supplies most of the medial surface and the posterior portion of the lateral surface of the pinna. Lesser occipital nerve: Innervates the upper part of the medial surface. Auriculotemporal nerve (B): Provides sensation to the tragus and crus of the helix. Arnold's nerve (C): Also known as the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), it supplies the concha and the adjacent area on the medial side. Facial nerve (CN VII) (C): Works alongside Arnold's nerve to innervate the concha and the area behind the ear.

questions.text: A female singer presents with hoarseness of voice and difficulty singing in a high pitch. On laryngoscopy, it was noted that one vocal cord is bowed, positioned lower than the other, and the associated muscle is shortened. Which muscle is likely affected in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cricothyroid The cricothyroid muscle, an intrinsic laryngeal muscle, is responsible for elongating and tensing the vocal cords to produce higher pitches. Along with the vocalis muscle, it adjusts vocal cord tension. The cricothyroid muscle’s function is influenced by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which facilitates pitch modulation.

questions.text: What is the marked structure of the cochlear implant shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ground electrode The marked structure in the radiology image of the cochlear implant is the ground electrode. A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It can be used in a patient with bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A patient presented with nasal congestion and upon examination, nasal polyps were observed. A coronal CT scan of the patient was taken and is as shown below. Which of the following sinus drainage pathways is likely to be affected? CT-Computed Tomography
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Maxillary In this patient with rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps, the CT scan indicates that the maxillary sinus is likely affected, as evidenced by the presence of a polyp in this sinus. Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults.

questions.text: During the post mortem examination following finding is seen. What is this indicative of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Smothering Abrasions around the mouth, cheeks, lips or lesions within the lips may reliably indicate smothering. The non-specific signs of death due to asphyxia: - Petechial haemorrhages in the face, eyebrows, eyelids, forehead, ears, conjunctiva, sclera – When they occur in the visceral pleura, they are called Tardieu’s spots - Emphysematous, congested lungs with serosanguinous fluid exudates in alveoli. - Cyanosis or dark-coloured blood due to accumulation of CO2 - Congestion of the larynx with slight oozing

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy was brought by police, and accused of sexual assault, but the boy claims to be a minor (16 years old). Which radiographs will you order to solve this discrepancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Wrist and knee joint

Wrist and knee joint radiographs will be ordered to solve this discrepancy as lower end of radius and upper end of tibia fuse at 18-19 years. If these joints are fused, It is certain that the boy is more than 18 years and his claim is false.

questions.text: A man sexually aroused when he wears his female partner’s dress and heels. He denies getting attracted to male. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transvestic fetishism

The given scenario is suggestive of transvestic fetishism.

It is a paraphilia characterized by recurrent sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges, or behavior involving the wearing of clothes of the opposite sex and appearing as a member of the opposite sex. It is also called transvestic fetishism. It is usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to a child 8 months after the death of her husband. The in-laws claim that the child is not their son, however, the DNA testing confirms the paternity. The child is known as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posthumous child

The child delivered after the death of the biological father, or a child delivered after the death of the biological mother, usually when 
delivered by a cesarean section is a posthumous child.

Legal issues involved with a posthumous child are legitimacy, Inheritance of property, and the case of compensation for slander against the mother.

questions.text: The railway police has bought a person with suspected poisoning. On examination, he was confused with slurred speech, hot skin, dry mouth, dilated pupils. What is the probable poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Datura

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Datura poisoning.

The two species are jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. Poisoning leads to delirium, hallucinations, and seizures. Additionally, other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia may present,

questions.text: A police officer brought a child to the hospital. There is redness and tenderness around perianal region. A rectal swab is taken and the image given below is the finding. What test is it indicative of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Barberio test

The test done in this scenario is the Barberio test.

Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic picric acid solution is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

questions.text: Rigor mortis is well established in 12-24 hours after death. What is the order of appearance of rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Head to toe

The order of appearance of rigor mortis is from head to toe.

Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head and continues downwards the body. It disappears in the same order of appearance. Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has consumed overdose of iron syrup, around 60mg/kg. Which among the following is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

BAL

The clinical scenario points to iron toxicity, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine), calcium EDETATE and DTPA whereas Dimercaprol, also known as BAL (British anti-Lewisite), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson’s disease.

choices.text: Proceeding held in a different location

questions.text: A sexual assault survivor had to testify in court and an in-camera trial was conducted. What is an “in-camera” trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Closed court proceedings

‘In-camera trial’ is a closed court proceeding in which the case is heard in private i.e. in court where general public is excluded.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for syndromic diagnosis of infected cases like meningitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Multiplex PCR

Multiplex PCR can be used for syndromic diagnosis of meningitis.

A syndromic diagnosis is a method of diagnosing infectious diseases that uses a single test to screen for multiple pathogens that could be causing a specific set of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient receiving chemotherapy develops pneumonia with skin lesions. Microscopy of specimen from skin lesions showed broad based budding with a thick capsule. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Blastomycosis

In this case of an immunocompromised patient with pneumonia and skin lesions, the microscopy of specimens from skin lesions showing broad-based budding with a thick capsule suggests the diagnosis of Blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermitidis.

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially, in the lungs and skin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came to the OPD with a febrile illness of 2 days, associated with abdominal tenderness, malaise and diarrhoea. He had a fever with bradycardia and BP was noted as 110/70 mmHg. He lives in a crowded neighborhood with poor sanitation where many others have reported similar complaints recently. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Blood culture

This patient’s history of fever with relative bradycardia, abdominal tenderness, and similar cases in the neighbourhood suggests enteric fever. It is caused by Salmonella typhi or paratyphi. Out of the given options, blood culture is the most sensitive test in this patient.

questions.text: A child presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and perianal itching for the past 3 days. The mother found a white thread-like structure in the child's night clothes and brought the worm to the clinician. A perianal swab was collected, and microscopy of the swab and the worm is shown in the images. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enterobius vermicularis The likely causative organism for the child’s abdominal pain, diarrhoea, perianal itching, and the white thread-like worm found in the night clothes is Enterobius vermicularis, charaterised by the worm’s pointed end and wing-like cuticular expansions (cervical alae) shown in the left image, and the colourless, non-bile stained, planoconvex eggs with an outer albuminous layer that stick to each other and other objects.

questions.text: A male patient comes to you with a history of UTI, the cause of which is suspected to be bacteria. Which of the following is used by the bacteria for adherence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fimbriae

Bacteria utilise fimbriae for adherence. Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function of ordinary pili and sex pili.

questions.text: A thalassemia patient has received multiple blood transfusions. Aplastic crisis can occur in this patient due to infection from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Parvovirus

An aplastic crisis in this patient is triggered by parvovirus infection, which infects and destroys red cell precursors, leading to a temporary halt in erythropoiesis. This results in a shortened lifespan of RBCs. The immune system typically clears the virus within 1-2 weeks. Aplastic crisis can occur in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias such as sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients often show symptoms of illness, including fever, malaise, pallor, tachycardia, and tachypnea due to severe anemia, and may or may not have a rash.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer comes with complaints of high-grade fever with chills, retro-orbital pain and conjunctival suffusion. On examination, he has severe calf tenderness. Lab examination shows hypokalemia and neutropenia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Leptospirosis

The clinical presentation of high-grade fever with chills, retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, severe calf tenderness, and lab findings of hypokalemia and neutropenia is indicative of leptospirosis. This zoonotic infection, caused by spirochetes from the Leptospira genus, often begins with flu-like symptoms, including sudden fever, chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia, particularly in the calves, abdomen, and back. Severe forms of leptospirosis can progress rapidly and may lead to Weil’s syndrome, which has a high fatality rate.

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of oysters comes with complaints of nausea, vomiting and crampy abdominal pain. The culture of the organism showed the Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vibrio parahemolyticus

Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahemolyticus.

On Wagatsuma agar (blood agar with 2% salt), pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic, while non- pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is due to a heat- stable hemolysin. They produce green-coloured colonies on the TCBS agar as they do not ferment sucrose.

questions.text: A man is having petechial rashes with a previous history of meningitis. He was vaccinated at the age of 5 years. Now, Brudzinski and Kernig’s signs were positive. Microscopy showed gram negative diplococci. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Neisseria Meningitidis

The clinical presentation suggests fulminant meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis. This organism is an aerobic, gram-negative, nonmotile diplococcus that is positive for catalase and oxidase. It oxidizes glucose and maltose but not lactose or sucrose. Typically, the bacteria spread from the nasopharynx to the meninges via the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve after an initial flu-like infection

choices.text: Biofilm provides resistance, necessitating catheter removal
Biofilm does not affect antibiotic susceptibility
Biofilm can be removed from the catheter

questions.text: A patient with a central line on long-term IV antibiotics develops a fever. Blood cultures reveal Staphylococcus epidermidis and biofilm formation. Which statement about its antibiotic resistance is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Biofilm provides resistance, necessitating catheter removal

In a patient with a central line on long-term IV antibiotics and biofilm formation in cultures, the appropriate action is to remove the catheter, as biofilms confer resistance. Biofilms consist of structured microcolonies encased in a self-produced glycocalyx, and the bacteria within them are typically less metabolically active.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations in a patient with desert rheumatism showed dimorphic and thermal fungi with arthrospores. What is the causative organism of desert rheumatism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Coccidioides immitis

Coccidioidomycosis, also referred to as Valley fever or desert rheumatism, is a fungal infection in mammals caused by Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii. The initial infection typically presents as a respiratory illness, with symptoms similar to bronchitis or pneumonia that usually resolve within a few weeks. The hallmark triad of coccidioidomycosis, known as "desert rheumatism," consists of fever, joint pain, and erythema nodosum.

questions.text: A farmer from South East India presents with fever, respiratory distress and neurological deficits. The vector of the causative organism is shown below. What is the associated organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nipah virus

The given clinical scenario along with the vector bat is suggestive of infection from the nipah virus.

Nipah virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus. It is a zoonotic virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family.

choices.text: Carriers can be treated with Rifampicin
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk
Metronidazole is the drug of choice

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents with fever, headache, and vomiting for the past 3 days. She has been living in an army recruitment camp for three weeks. Examination reveals neck stiffness and a maculopapular rash on her trunk and extremities. Which statement about her likely disease is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Metronidazole is the drug of choice

The clinical features indicate meningococcal meningitis, for which metronidazole is not the drug of choice. The preferred treatment is a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone, while chloramphenicol is used for patients with penicillin allergies. The disease is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive diplococcus. Outbreaks typically occur in crowded settings such as army camps or dormitories.

choices.text: The test must be repeated with a fresh specimen
Diagnose and treat as a urinary tract infection
Normal skin commensal grown on culture that needs to be proven

questions.text: A young sexually active female presented with a symptomatic UTI, and urinalysis and cultures revealed novobiocin-resistant coagulase-negative staphylococcus at a count of 104 cells/HPF. Which statement is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diagnose and treat as urinary tract infection A young sexually active female with symptomatic UTI and urinalysis showing novobiocin-resistant coagulase-negative staphylococcus at a count of 104 cells/HPF should be diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and treated accordingly. Staphylococcus saprophyticus, a gram-positive, coagulase-negative staphylococcus, is non-pigmented, resistant to novobiocin, and non-hemolytic on blood agar. It is a common cause of cystitis in women and is part of the normal flora of the skin and periurethral area, leading to infections in sexually active females.

questions.text: A 28-year-old truck driver presents with painful multiple ulcers on his penis 3 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Chancroid

Multiple painful genital ulcers 3 days after unprotected Intercourse is indicative of Chancroid or Soft Chancre.

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It causes painful genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy, which can lead to buboes. Auto-inoculation may cause new ulcers to merge with existing ones, referred to as “kissing ulcers.”

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain and hoarseness for one month, and on a CT angiogram, the following image is seen, what is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Saccular aneurysm of distal aorta

The provided CT scan reveals a saccular aneurysm of the distal aorta, and the patient's symptoms of chest pain and hoarseness further support this diagnosis. Other conditions can be ruled out: Option A, stenosis of the aortic arch, would present as a narrowing rather than an aneurysmal dilation and typically causes symptoms related to reduced blood flow to the upper body. Option B, aortic dissection, usually manifests with tearing chest pain radiating to the back and would be indicated by a double lumen or false lumen on imaging. Lastly, Option D, coarctation of the aorta, generally presents with hypertension in the upper limbs and weak or absent pulses in the lower limbs.

questions.text: This is the radiograph of a child with a foreign body in the oesophagus. What is the sign seen in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Double ring sign

The presence of a halo sign or double ring sign is indicative of the foreign body being a button battery. Button batteries and sharp objects in the oesophagus and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal.

questions.text: A patient presents with a one-month history of lethargy, headache, fever, and vomiting. Shortly after being admitted to the hospital, the patient tragically passes away. Radiological imaging reveals multiple cystic lesions in the cerebrum with invasion into the ventricles and subarachnoid space. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Neurocysticercosis

The given clinical sceriario along with CT showing cystic lesions in the brain, particularly within the cerebrum, ventricles, and subarachnoid space is clearly suggestive of neurocysticercosis. Neurocysticercosis is a form of cysticercosis caused by Taenia solium.It usually presents with seizures and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion. Papilledema may develop secondary to hydrocephalus

questions.text: A patient complains of severe headache. NCCT and CT angiography images are as below. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Subarachnoid hemorrhage

The clinical manifestations of severe headache with CT revealing blood in the basal cistern point to a diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region (65%), or in the Sylvian fissure (30%).

questions.text: An elderly woman with a known history of Myasthenia Gravis presents with symptoms including fatigue, facial congestion, dilated neck veins, and breathlessness, which are indicative of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thymoma

The diagnosis of myasthenia gravis along with the CT scan image showing an anterior mediastinal mass, is suggestive of thymoma.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old infant presented to the ER with projectile vomiting. USG abdomen findings of the infant are given below. Probable diagnosis is

USG-Ultrasonography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

The probable diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis since the cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis on USG.

Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called Nipple sign. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

questions.text: An infant presents with respiratory distress. He has a previous history of recurrent respiratory infections. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Congenital malformations of the airway

The given clinical scenario along with the image is suggestive of congenital malformations of the airway.

Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is a condition where more normal lung tissue is mixed with hamartomatous or dysplastic lung tissue, usually confined to one lobe. The lesion most likely originates from a maldevelopment of terminal bronchiolar structures caused by an embryologic injury that occurred prior to the 35th day of gestation.

questions.text: A young patient presents with nasal polyps and rhinosinusitis. X-ray and clinical images are as below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Kartagener’s syndrome

The given clinical scenario along with an X-ray showing dextrocardia, CT showing maxillary polyp, and endoscopy showing nasal polyp is suggestive of Kartagener’s syndrome.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. When a patient has bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus triad, he is known to have Kartagener syndrome. It occurs due to the absence of protein dynein in the A tubules of the respiratory mucosa.

questions.text:
Given below is a USG taken at approximately 8 weeks of gestation. Which anomaly can be observed here?

USG-ultrasound
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Anencephaly

The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin. This is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.
Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly.
